content.text: Welcome to web2json, a tool for converting web pages into structured JSON format. This documentation will guide you through almost everything you need to know about installing and using this multi-module Python package.
web2json is a tool that transforms web pages into structured JSON data. This is useful for:

items.text: Content analysis and data mining: Extract and analyze web content easily
Archival and offline access: Save web content in a standardized format
Integration with data processing pipelines: Feed web content into your data workflows
Content transformation and republishing: Reformat web content for different purposes
Machine learning dataset preparation: Create structured data for training models

content.text: JSON (JavaScript Object Notation) is used because it’s:

items.text: A structured format that’s easy to parse
Language-agnostic, working with virtually any programming language
Ideal for APIs and data processing
Able to preserve content hierarchy and relationships
Perfect for selective content extraction

content.text: web2json requires Python 3.6 or higher. The latest stable version is recommended.
To check if Python is installed and which version you have, open a terminal or command prompt and type:
If a command shows a version number at or above 3.6, you’re ready to go. If not, you’ll need to install or update Python.
The following steps assume that you are using Windows 11 with the latest updates.

items.text: Launch Command Prompt (Hint: type cmd in Search)
In Command Prompt type python and hit Enter
This should launch Microsoft Store app and offer you to get Python
Get Python and wait for it to install
Verify your installation by typing python --version in Command Prompt

content.text: This guide provides step-by-step instructions for installing web2json on both macOS and Windows systems. We’ll use a consistent approach with command-line instructions for both operating systems, making the process straightforward even for beginners.

In this process, we will use a Python virtual environment (venv). A virtual environment acts as a special container for your Python programs; it keeps web2json and its required components separate from other Python programs on your computer. Think of it as giving web2json its own private room instead of sharing space with others.

items.text: Prevent conflicts between different Python programs
Ensure web2json has exactly the right components it needs
Make it easier to manage updates and changes

content.text: We will set up web2json in your Home folder, within a subfolder named Tools. The steps are as follows:

items.text: Download the latest release from GitHub
Save this archive file to your Downloads folder
Open Terminal
Open it via Applications → Utilities → Terminal, or use Spotlight with Command+Space and type “Terminal”
Create a suitable folder structure Terminal windowmkdir -p ~/Tools
Create a Tools folder if it doesn’t exist:
Unarchive the downloaded package Terminal windowcd ~/Downloads Terminal windowtar -xzvf web2json.tar.gz
Navigate to your Downloads folder:
Move the files to your Tools folder Terminal windowmv web2json ~/Tools/web2json
Navigate to the web2json folder Terminal windowcd ~/Tools/web2json
Set up a virtual environment Terminal windowpython3 -m venv .venv
Activate the virtual environment Terminal windowsource .venv/bin/activate
You should see (.venv) at the beginning of your command prompt
Install the package with dependencies Terminal windowpip install -e .
This installs web2json with required dependencies
Create a shell function
This will allow web2json to run from anywhere
This assumes you are using the Z shell (Zsh), which is a default shell since macOS 10.15:
Open your ~/.zshrc file, for example via nano ~/.zshrc
Add this shell function: web2json() { (cd ~/Tools/web2json && source .venv/bin/activate && python -m web2json "$@" && deactivate)}
Reload the shell via source ~/.zshrc or launch a new Terminal instance
Test your installation (after restarting) Terminal windowweb2json -u https://resoltico.com/en/tools/web2json/ -o test_output

content.text: Note: If you’re unsure whether Python is installed on your system, please refer to the Requirements section above before proceeding further. We will set up web2json in your Home folder, within a subfolder named Tools. The steps are as follows:

items.text: Download the latest release from GitHub
Save this archive file to your Downloads folder
Open Command Prompt
Press Windows+R, type “cmd”, and press Enter
Create a suitable folder structure Terminal windowmkdir %USERPROFILE%\Tools
Create a Tools folder if it doesn’t exist:
Unarchive the downloaded package Terminal windowcd %USERPROFILE%\Downloads Terminal windowtar -xzvf web2json.tar.gz
Navigate to your Downloads folder:
Move the extracted contents to your Tools folder Terminal windowmove "web2json" "%USERPROFILE%\Tools\web2json"
Navigate to the web2json folder Terminal windowcd %USERPROFILE%\Tools\web2json
Set up a virtual environment Terminal windowpython -m venv .venv
Activate the virtual environment Terminal window.venv\Scripts\activate
You should see (.venv) at the beginning of your command prompt
Install the package with dependencies Terminal windowpip install -e .
This installs web2json with required dependencies
Run the Windows setup script
This creates a system-wide batch file that makes web2json accessible from anywhere
The script also adds the Tools directory to your PATH environment variable
IMPORTANT: Restart your computer
Windows requires a system restart for PATH changes to take effect
Without restarting, new Command Prompt windows won’t recognize the web2json command
This is a limitation of how Windows handles environment variables
Alternative methods until you restart
If you want to use web2json before restarting, you have these options:
Use the full path: %USERPROFILE%\Tools\web2json.bat -u https://example.com -o output
Navigate to the Tools directory first: Terminal windowcd %USERPROFILE%\Toolsweb2json -u https://example.com -o output
Test your installation (after restarting) Terminal windowweb2json -u https://resoltico.com/en/tools/web2json/ -o test_output
Launch Command Prompt
Execute this command to verify the set up:
-u or --url: Process a single webpage Terminal windowweb2json -u https://example.com/article
-f or --file: Process multiple URLs from a text file (one URL per line) Terminal windowweb2json -f urls.txt

In the above command, web2json will look for the urls.txt file inside its installation folder (i.e. \Tools\web2json\urls.txt). Alternatively, you can also specify the path, for example: web2json -f ~/Downloads/urls.txt on macOS or web2json -f %USERPROFILE%\Downloads/urls.txt on Windows.
-o or --output: Set custom output name for the JSON file Terminal windowweb2json -u https://example.com/article -o my_article
--output-dir: Change where files are saved (default: fetched_jsons directory inside installation folder)
macOS example Terminal windowweb2json -u https://example.com --output-dir ~/Downloads
Windows example Terminal windowweb2json -u https://example.com --output-dir %USERPROFILE%\Downloads
--preserve-styles: Keep HTML styling (bold, italic, etc.) in the output Terminal windowweb2json -u https://example.com --preserve-styles
-v or --verbose : Show detailed progress information Terminal windowweb2json -u https://example.com -v

<i> , <em> - Italic text
<code> - Code snippets

And others defined in configuration
